markdown.markdown:
I specialize in measuring greenhouse gas (GHG) exchange in permafrost environments.

::::{.columns}
:::{.column width=50%}

* PhD in Geography from UBC in 2023
* I started as a research scientists with the GSC in summer 2024
  + "Cross posted" between GSC Northern and Pacific

:::

:::{.column width=50%}

![2024 Fish Island Field Campaign](images/me.jpg)

:::
::::


## Framing the Problem

The Arctic is warming ~3x faster than the global average.  

![Image source: [Skeeter 2022](https://june-skeeter.github.io/ThesisDefense/#/)](images/CMIP.png)



## Carbon-Climate Feedback

Climate change is shifting the carbon balance of the Arctic, which has far reaching global implications.

::::{.columns}
:::{.column width=50%}


* Extended growing seasons
  + ↑ Carbon *uptake*
* Permafrost degradation
  + ↑ Carbon **emission**
* Flooding & coastal erosion
  + ↑ Carbon **emission**


:::

:::{.column width=50%}

![Niglintgak thaw slump](images/Slump.jpg)

:::
::::

## Importance of Methane

![Source: [GRID-Arendal, 2020](https://storymaps.arcgis.com/stories/c163de04de7849cdb917fee88015dd73)](images/MethaneSources.png)


## A Methane Hot-spot

The Mackenzie River Delta is hot-spot for methane in the Canadian Arctic.

* Aircraft and satellite have detected significant methane emissions

![Source: [Kohnert et al. (2017)](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-017-05783-2/figures/2)](images/Kohnert.webp)

## Biologic Emissions

::::{.columns}
:::{.column width=65%}

The limited field based measurements available suggest of substantial growing season emissions over where permafrost is continuous.

![](images/Asci.png)

:::
:::{.column width=35%}

![Source: [Skeeter 2023](https://open.library.ubc.ca/soa/cIRcle/collections/ubctheses/24/items/1.0421939)](images/DeltaMap.png)

:::
::::

## Geologic Methane

In discontinuous permafrost, some gas seeps are visible to the naked eye!

::::{.columns}
:::{.column width=50%}

* More work is needed:
  + Map sources
  + Quantify emissions
  + Identify potential remediation strategies

:::
:::{.column width=50%}

![](images/Bubbles.mp4)

:::
::::

## How do we measure emissions?

Eddy covariance (EC) is a principal method to monitor landscape-scale fluxes.

::::{.columns}
:::{.column width=50%}

* Measures wind velocity and gas concentration at high frequency (20 Hz)
* Gives a semi-continuous time series of half-hourly fluxes 

:::
:::{.column width=50%}

![](images/EC.jpg)

:::
::::

## Limited Observations

::::{.columns}
:::{.column width=50%}

EC systems are expensive, difficult to operate in remote environments, and require meticulous analysis.

+ Bias towards accessible sites
+ Canadian Arctic is under-represented

:::

:::{.column width=50%}

![Source: [Skeeter 2023](https://open.library.ubc.ca/soa/cIRcle/collections/ubctheses/24/items/1.0421939)](images/Fig1.png)


:::
::::



## Swiss Cheese Lake

::::{.columns}
:::{.column width="50%"}

To reduce the uncertainties regarding the trajectory of greenhouse gas fluxes in the Mackenzie River delta, an Eddy Covariance system was installed in summer 2024 at an outer delta sedge wetland site underlain by continuous permafrost. As long as there is sufficient solar power available to run the system, it measures the ecosystem-atmosphere exchange of methane and carbon dioxide and collects ancillary data that include solar radiation, air temperature, soil temperature profiles, and water table depth. 


The primary long-term objectives of the station are: 1) to understand non-growing season fluxes, with particular focus on the snowmelt and freeze-up periods, and 2) to estimate the ecosystem's net greenhouse gas balance by accounting for the disproportionally high global warming potential of methane fluxes. Preliminary results indicate the site is a source of atmospheric methane and a sink for atmospheric carbon dioxide during the growing season. There are not yet sufficient data to assess non-growing season fluxes or the net greenhouse gas balance. An overview of findings covering summer–early autumn 2024 will be presented along with a plans for upcoming seasons and a discussion of the broader context and implications of this work.


:::
:::{.column width="50%"}

<iframe src="fieldSiteMap.html"width="500" height="800"></iframe>

:::
::::
